Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Engineering-Driven Modeling of Multi-Resolution Data for Surface Variation Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This GOALI project develops methodologies and algorithms to reduce surface shape variation, enabling cost-effective high-precision machining by integrating process physics with multi-resolution surface data for quality diagnosis and monitoring. The integration of the process physics model and multi-resolution data will improve surface data modeling, variation prediction accuracy, and interpretability. Based on the improved data model, a cost-effective surface measurement strategy and monitoring scheme will be developed by which abnormal process variations can be detected and identified with reduced false alarm rates. The model will also improve surface variation diagnosis. By combining the modeling and monitoring approaches, a two-level surface variation control methodology is established to improve surface quality for multistage machining processes. The PI and co-PIs will collaborate with major US automakers and/or powertrain system suppliers for data acquisition, experiments, algorithm verification and validation, and technology transfer.

The outcome of this research provides new insights into surface variations in multistage machining processes and will transform in-plant quality control practice from dimensional variation reduction to surface shape variation control. If successful, this project will enhance US manufacturing competitiveness by improving powertrain machining precision and quality. The surface modeling and control framework established in this research focuses on face milling and can potentially benefit other surface machining applications. In addition, the methodology of surface variation control established in this research will contribute to development of a novel optical surface measurement system that can intelligently select metrology resolution and determine defective surface regions. The surface variation monitoring scheme can also be extended to quality control for micro manufacturing processes by reducing the measurement time of high-definition metrology such as atomic force microscopy and 3D profilometry.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
In collaboration with Coherix Inc. and its major US customer in US auto industry, this GOALI project develops data fusion algorithm to improve modeling of multi-resolution surface data and thereby improve surface quality prediction, monitoring, diagnosis, and quality control. The outcomes and findings from this project can be summarized as follows, i.e.,

Intellectual Merit:

1.  The project discovered a number of new surface shape problems using high-definition metrology systems and identified the root cause (Fig. 1). The discovery leads to new engineering knowledge on the surface variation generation mechanism and quality control methods.

2. The project delivers a modeling method and demonstrates that fusing the surface quality data measured in in-plant with the engineering process knowledge as learned from high-definition data can significantly improve surface quality prediction with high precision without having to increase measurement efforts. The outcome helps powertrain plants establish cost-effective quality control of high-precision surface machining.

3. The project delivers a knowledge-sharing and transferring method to help improve the monitoring of surface process variations given limited historical data. This outcome will help a new manufacturing plant to efficiently build a statistical baseline to monitor the process repeatability, and stability with very limited historical data are available.

4. The project develops a new spatial data monitoring method not only to detect abnormal surfaces but locate the problem on surfaces with sufficient statistical confidence. The results published on IIE Transactions is recognized as a featured article and received the best application award at IISE Annual Conference in 2017.

5. Based on the surface model and discovered engineering knowledge about surface variations, a cost-effective surface variation control method is developed for improving machined surface quality. The method has been tested successfully by experiments and an in-plant trial in an engine plant (Fig. 2). This research received one best paper award from ASME Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference and ASME Blackall Machine Tool and Gage Award.

6. New research on surface mating assembly has been developed based on this project, aiming to monitor and diagnose potential leakage problems during surface mating for powertrain part assembly. 

7. The research activities in this project have generated at least ten peer-reviewed journal papers and conference papers.  Two journal papers have received various awards and recognition from ASME and IIE.

Broader Impacts:

1. Industry impacts:

The powertrain manufacturing industry realizes the significant values of 3D surface data in bolstering product quality. Using the multi-dimensional data, this project helps powertrain manufacturing plants develop cost-effective quality inspection control strategy for surface manufacturing processes. A preliminary trial of the suggested quality control method in an engine plant has resulted in at least 20% surface flatness improvement for machining engine head deck faces. The improved surface quality will reduce sealing problems and distortions thus reducing scraps and warranty cost. The outcome of these improvements will contribute to increasing the US automakers' competitiveness. 

2. Impacts on other applications:

a. The surface variation modeling and monitoring scheme can be extended to various manufacturing applications that involve spatial data and process information. Potential applications include the surface quality control in micromachining and additive manufacturing.

b. The progressive measurement and monitoring strategy for spatial data developed in this project reduce the measurement time of high-definition metrology. As such, it has great potential applications for improving measurement efficiency of high-resolution metrology system in micro and nanomanufacturing such as micro/nano 3D profilometry. 

c. The data fusion modeling methodology for spatial data was applied to other applications including solar panel PV data forecasting and electricity load forecasting for the smart city. Two journal papers were completed and submitted.

3. Education and training:

Educational and training opportunities were created for graduate and undergraduate students. 

a. The project provides the support for two Ph.D. students at two universities on their dissertation research. At least two chapters in each of their dissertation are supported by this project. The two Ph.D. students also received training in in-plant data measurement, experimental design, and machining processes

b. Three other graduate students at Florida State University received partial support from this grant on data acquisition and manufacturing system design/optimization. One of the students received his master degree in Industrial Engineering.

c. Three undergraduate students (including one African American from Florida A&M University- a historically black college/university) received the training in developing data acquisition systems and machining experiments (Fig. 3). 

d. The results were demonstrated to the public through annual open house organized at the PI's research institute. 

e. Partial results were presented to engineers in Coherix Inc. and powertrain manufacturing practitioners through an industry training session and several teleconferences with Coherix. A joint research proposal was created for Ford University Research Program. 

f. The outcome of this project contributes to case studies for developing a new graduate course on Advanced Manufacturing Process Control at Florida State University-Florida A&M University College of Engineering.

Modified by: Hui Wang

The outcomes and findings from this project can be summarized as follows, i.e., Intellectual Merit: 1. Three other graduate students at Florida State University received partial support from this grant on data acquisition and manufacturing system design/optimization. One of the students received his master degree in Industrial Engineering. c. Partial results were presented to engineers in Coherix Inc. and powertrain manufacturing practitioners through an industry training session and several teleconferences with Coherix. A joint research proposal was created for Ford University Research Program. f. The outcome of this project contributes to case studies for developing a new graduate course on Advanced Manufacturing Process Control at Florida State University-Florida A&M University College of Engineering.
